body:
@snehankekre yes, it works exactly as you described, a first callback call is for removing a file, and a second one for uploading a new one, according to how the widget logic is written. 

We can have multiple solutions to fix this:
1) Try to rewrite widget logic to distinguish between "file_removed"->"new file uploaded", and "new file uploaded that should trigger old file removal first" situations. 
2) Disallow file uploads for single file uploader, when file already uploaded on front-end. 

I think the second option is easier to implement (just disallow uploading a new file for a single file uploader when a file has already been uploaded), although it is more Product decision. 


In a situation, where you need to trigger the on_change callback for a single file uploader only when a new file is uploaded (I think that could be a popular usage and intention of your code snippet), you can filter "remove" events, by accessing file uploader session_state itself. 

```
import streamlit as st

if 'ctr' not in st.session_state:
    st.session_state['ctr'] = 0


def uploader_callback():
    if st.session_state.file_uploader is not None:
        st.session_state['ctr'] += 1
        print('Uploaded file #%d' % st.session_state['ctr'])


st.file_uploader(label="File uploader", on_change=uploader_callback, key="file_uploader")
```

CC: @willhuang1997

This is definitely a bug and not the intended behavior. The intended behavior should be that the callback triggers only once when a new file is uploaded, no matter if a file has been uploaded before or not. That is, it should trigger when the uploaded file "changes" â€“ therefore it's called `on_change` ðŸ˜‰

We should also definitely solve that on the eng side and not by restricting uploading new files. That would decrease the powerfulness of `st.file_uploader` a lot.

I cant believe this issue is still open in 1.32.0
Duh!

issue.title: Fix double script/callback run when replacing a file

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit â€” A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
There's already a thorough description of the problem and its root cause in the associated issue, so
we don't duplicate it in this PR. The fix for this issue was to maintain a state variable keeping track
of whether we're in the process of replacing a file in the code path where the file uploader only allows
for a single file upload. The state is used to set the file uploader's status to "updating" while in
the process of replacing a file, which ensures that we don't double-trigger a script run. 

Closes #4877

body: This is still not fixed, why are we closing?

Hi @DarkCTO ðŸ‘‹  What version of Streamlit are you using? 

This bug was [fixed](https://docs.streamlit.io/develop/quick-reference/release-notes#version-1340) in `streamlit>=1.34.0`. You can confirm this is fixed in the latest version like so:

```py
import streamlit as st

st.version.STREAMLIT_VERSION_STRING

if 'ctr' not in st.session_state:
    st.session_state['ctr'] = 0

def uploader_callback():
    if st.session_state['file_uploader'] is not None:
        st.session_state['ctr'] += 1
        print('Uploaded file #%d' % st.session_state['ctr'])

st.file_uploader(
    label="File uploader", on_change=uploader_callback, key="file_uploader"
)
```

![fileuploader-callback-fixed](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b2988997-f320-4c4d-8dcb-45ee2dda83fb)
